Into his Closet to put off his robes,
He like a Player leaves his part off too;
Open his brest, and with a Sunne-beame search it,
There's no such man; this King of gilded clay,
Within is uglinesse, lust, treachery,
And a base soule, tho rard Collossus-high.

SP.SPEAKER: Daen.
SP.L: None till he speakes, and that we know his voyce:
Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Within Bal.
SP.L: An honest house-keeper in Rosemary-lane too,
If you dwell in the same parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Oh tis our honest Souldier, give him entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P:
Men show like coarses, for I meet few but are stuck with Rosemary: every one ask'd mee who was married to
day, and I told 'em Adultery and Repentance, and that shame and a Hagman followed'em to Church.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: There's but two parts to play, shame has done hers,
But execution must close up the Scane,
And for that cause these sprigs are worne by all,
Badges of Marriage, now of Funerall,
For death this day turnes Courtier

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: Who must dance with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: The King, and all that are our opposites:
That dartor This must flye into the Court
Either to shoot this blazing starre from Spaine,
Or else so long to wrap him up in clouds,
Till all the fatall fires in him burne out,
Leaving his State and conscience cleere from doubt
Of following uprores.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.L: Kill not, but surprize him.

SP.SPEAKER: Carl.
SP.L: Thats my voyce still.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Thine, Souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: Oh this Collicke of a kingdome, when the wind of treason gets amongst the small guts, what a rumbling and a roaring it keepes: and yet make the best of it you can, it goes out stinking: kill a King?

SP.SPEAKER: Daen.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: If men should pull the Sun out of heaven every time tis cclips'd, not all the Wax nor Tallow in Spaine woo'd serve to make us Candles for one yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.P: No way to purge the sicke State, but by opening a vaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: Is that your French Physicke? if every one of us shoo'd be whip'd according to our faults, to be lasht at a carts taile would be held but a ea-biting.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: What are you? come you from the King?

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: No? more no's? I know him, let him enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: gneor, I thanke your kind Intelligence,
The newes long since was sent nto our eares.
Yet we embrace your love, so fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Carl.
SP.L: Will you smell to a sprig of Rosemary?

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: Will you be hang'd?

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: This is either Signeor No, or no Signeor.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: He makes his love to us a warning-peece
To arme our selves against we come to Court,
Because the guard is doubled.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Tush, we care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: If any here armes his hand to cut off the head, le him first plucke out my throat: in any Noble Act I le wade chin-deepe with you: but to kill a King?

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.P: No, heare me—

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: You were better, my Lord, saile 500 times to Bantom in the West-Indies, than once to Barathrum in the Low-Countries: It's hot going under the line there, the Callen∣ture of the soule is a most miserable madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Turne then this wheele of Fate from shedding blood
Till with her owne hand Iustice weyes all.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Must then his Trul be once more sphear'd in Court
To triumph in my spoyles, in my ecclipses?
And I like moaping Iuno sit, whilst Iove
Varies his lust into five hundred shapes
Tostcale to his whores bed! no, Malateste,
Italian fires of Iealousie burne my marrow;
For to delude my hopes, the leacherous King
Cuts out this robe of cunning marriage,
To cover his Incontinence, which flames
Hot (as my fury) in his blacke desires:
I am swolne big with child of vengeance now,
And till deliver'd, feele the throws of hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Iust is your Indignation, high, and Noble,
And the brave heat of a true Florentine;
For Spaine Trumpets abroad her Interest
In the Kings heart, and with a blacke cole drawes
On every wall your scoff'd at injuries,
As one that has the refuse of her sheets,
And the sicke Autumne of the weakned King,
Where she drunke pleasures up in the full spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: That (Malateste) That, That Torrent wracks me
But Hymens Torch (held downe-ward) shall drop out,
And for it, the mad Furies swing their brands
About the Bride-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: The Priest that joynes them,
Our Twin-borne malediction.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Lowd may it speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: The herbs and flowers to strew the wedding way,
Be Cypresle, Eugh, cold Colliquintida.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Henbane and Poppey, and that magicall wed
Which Hags at midnight watch to catch the seed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: To these our execrations, and what mischiefe
Hell can but hatch in a distracted braine,
I le be the Executioner, tho it looke
So harrid it can fright e'ne murder backe.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Poyson his whor e to day, for thou shalt wait
On the Kings Cup, and when heated with wine
He cals to drinke the Brides health, Marry her
A liue to a gaping grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: At board?

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: At board.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: When she being guarded round about with friends,
Like a faire Iland, hem'd with Rockes and Seas,
What rescue shall I find?

SP.SPEAKER: Qe.
SP.L: Mine armes: dost faint?
Stood all the Pyrenoean hills that part
Spaine and our Country, on each others shoulders,
Burning with Aetnean flame, yet thou shouldst on,
As being my steele of resolution,
First striking sparkles from my finty brest:
Wert thou to catch the horses of the Sunne
Fast by their bridles, and to turne backe day,
Woodst thou not doo't (base coward) to make way
To the Italians second blise (revenge.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Were my bones threatned to the wheele of torture
I'le doo't.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: A Ravens voyce, and it likes me well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lop.
SP.L: The King expects your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: So, so, we come
To turne this Brides day to a day of doome.

DIV3.STAGE: A Banqet set out, Cornets sounding; Enter at one dore Lo∣pez, Valasco, Alanzo, No: after them King, Cadnall, with Don Cockadillie Bridegroome, Queene and Malateste af∣ter. At the other dore Alba, Carlo, Roderigo, Medina and Daenia leading Onaelia as Bride, Cornego and Iuanna after, Bartazar alone, Bride and Bridegroome kisse, and by the Cardinall are joyn'd hand in hand: King is very merry, hugging Medina very lovingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: For halfe Spaines weight in Ingots I'de not lose
This little man to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Nor for so much
Twice told, Sir, would I misse your kingly presence;
Mine eyes have lost th'acquaintance of your face
So long, and I so (little) late read o're
That Index of the royall booke your mind,
That scarce (without your Comment) can I tell
When in those leaves you turne o're smiles or frownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: 'Tis dimneste of your sight, no fault i'th letter:
Medina, you shall find that free from Errata's:
And for a proofe,
If I could breath my heart in welcomes forth,
This Hall should ring naught else; welcome Medina,
Good Marquesse Dania, Dons of Spaine all welcome:
My dearest love and Queene, be it your place
To entertaine the Bride, and doe her grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: With all the love I can, whose fire is such,
To give her heat, I cannot burue too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Contracted Bride, and Bridegroome sit,
Sweet flowres not pluck'd in season, lose their scent,
So will our pleasures; Father Cardiall,
Me thinkes this morning new-begins our reigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Peace had her Sabbath ne're till now in Spaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Where is our Noble Souldier Baltazar?
So close in conference with that Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: What thinkst thou of this great day, Baltazar?

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: Of this day? why as of a new play, if it ends well, all's well; all men are but Actors, now if you being the King, should be out of your part, or the Queene out of hers, or your Dons out of theirs, here's No wil never be out of his▪

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: 'Twere a lamentable peece of stuffe to see great Statesmen have vile Exits; but I hope there are nothing but plaudities in all your eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Mine I protest are free.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: And mine by heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Free from one good looke till the blow be given.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Wine; a full Cup crown'd to Medina's health.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Your Highnesse this day so much honors me,
That I to pay you what I truly owe,
My life shall venture for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dn.
SP.L: So shall mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Onaelia, you are sad: why frownes your brow?

SP.SPEAKER: Onae.
SP.L: A foolish memory of my past ills
Folds up my looke in furrowes of old care,
But my heart's merry, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Which mirth to heighten,
Your Bridegroome and your selfe first pledge this health
Which we begin to our high Constable.

DIV3.STAGE: Three Cups fild: 1. to the King. 2. to the Bridegroome. 3. to Onaela, with whom the King complements.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Is t speeding?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: As all our Spanish figs are.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Here's to Medina's heart with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: My hart shal pledge your hart i'th deepest draught
That ever Spanyard dranke.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Medina mockes me,
Because I wrong her with the largest Bowle:
I'le change with thee, Onlia.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Sir you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Feare you I cannot fetch it off!

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Malatete!

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: This is your scorne to her, because I am doing
This poorest honour to her: Musicke sound,
It goes were it ten fadoms to the ground.

DIV3.STAGE: Cornets. King drinkes, Queen and Mal. storms.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Fate strikes with the wrong weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Sweet royall Sir no more, it is too deepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Twill hurt your health sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Interrupt me in my drinke: tis off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Alas ir;
You have drunke your last, that poyson'd bowle I fill'd
Not to be put into your hand, but hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Poyson'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Descend blacke speckled soule to hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: The Queene has sent me thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: What new furie shakes now her snakes locks.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: I, I, tis I;
Whose soule is torne in peeces, till I send
This Hatlot home.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: More murders! save the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Balt.
SP.L: Rampant? let the Constable make a mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Keepe 'em asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: How is it, royall sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: I feele no poyson yet, onely mine eyes
Are putting out their lights: me thinks I feele
Deaths Icy fingers stroking downe my face; and now
I'me in a mortall cold sweat.

SP.SPEAKER: Qee.
SP.L: Deare my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Hence, call in my Physicians.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Thy Physician, Tyrant,
Dwels yonder, call on him or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Bloody Medina, stab'st thou Brutus too?

SP.SPEAKER: Daen.
SP.L: As hee is, so are we all.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: I burne,
My braines boyle in a Caldron, O one drop
Of water now to coole me.

SP.SPEAKER: Onae.
SP.L: Oh let him have Physicians.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Keepe her backo.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Physicians for my soule, I need none else;
You'll not deny me those: oh holy Father,
Is there no mercy hovering in a cloud
For me a miserable King so drench'd
In perjury and murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Oh Sir great store.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Come downe, come quickly doue.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I'le forthwith send
For a grave Fryer to be your Confessor.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Doe, doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: And he shall cure your wounded soule:
Ftch him good Sovldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.L: So good a worke I'le hasten.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Onaelia! oh shee's drown'd in teares! Onaelia,
Let me not dye unpardoned at thy hands.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Baltazar, Sebastian as a Fryer, with others.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Here comes a better Surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Haile my good Sonne,
I come to be thy ghostly Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Ha? my child tis my Sebastian, or some spirit
Sent in his shape to fright me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: 'Tis no gobling, i, feele; your owne flesh and blood, and much younger than you tho he be bald, and cals you son; had I bin as ready to ha cut his sheeps throat, as you were to send him to the shambles, he had bleated no more; there's lesse chalke upon you score of sinnes by these round o'es.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Oh my dul soule looke up, thou art somwhat lighter,
Noble Medina, see Sebstian lives:
Onaelia cease to weepe, Sebastian livea;
Fetch me my Crowne: my sweetest pretty Fryer,
Can my hands do't, I le raise thee one step higher
Th'ast beene in heavens house all this while sweet boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I had but course cheere.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Thou couldst ne're fare better:
Religious houses are those hyves, where Bees
Make honey for mens soules: I tell thee, Boy,
A Fryery is a Cube, which stiongly stands,
Fashioned by men, supported by heavens hands:
Orders of holy Priest-hood are as high
I'th eyes of Angels, as a Kings dignity:
Both these unto a Crowne give the hill weight,
And both are thine: you that our Contract know,
See how I seale it with this Marriage;
My blessing and Spaines kingdome both be thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Long live Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Onae.
SP.L: Doff that Fryers course gray;
And since hee's crownd a King, clothe him like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Oh no: those are right overaigne Ornaments;
Had I beene cloth'd so, I had never
My worke is almost finish'd: where's my Queene?

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Here peece-meale torne by Furies.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Onaelia!
Your hand Paulina too, Onaelia yours:
This hand (the pledge of my twice broken faith)
By you usurp'd is her Inheritance;
My love is turn'd, see as my fate is turn'd,
Thus they to day laugh, yesterday which mourn'd:
I pardon thee my death; let her be
Backe into Florence with a trebled dowry;
Death comes: oh now I see what late I fear'd!
A Contrat broke, tho piec'd up nere so well,
Heaven sees, earth suffes, but it ends in hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Onae.
SP.L: Oh I could dye with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Since the bright spheare
I mov'd in falls, alas what make I here?

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: The hammers of black mischiefe now cease beating,
Yet some Irons still are heating: you, Sir Bridegroome,
(Set all this while up as a marke to shoot at)
We here discharge you of your bed-fellow,
Shee loves no Barbars washing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.L: My Balls are sav'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Med.
SP.L: Be it your charge, so please you reverend Sir,
To see the late Queene safely sent to Florence:
My Neece Oaelia, and that trusty Souldier,
We doe appoint to guarp the Infant King:
Other distractions, Time must reconcile;
The State is poyson'd like a Crocodile.
